clinical_validity.gcep: Glaucoma and Neuro-Ophthalmology Gene Curation Expert Panel

generif.text: terf interacts with TRIM44;TRIM44 inhibited ubiquitination of terf, and thus stabilized the protein.
Clinical trial of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
Overexpression of the TRIM44 protein was significantly correlated with an advanced type of macroscopic appearance.
rim44 functions as a positive regulator of the virus-triggered immune response by enhancing the stability of VISA.
Trim44 promotes non-small cell lung cancer development through activation of NF-kappaB signaling via upregulating CXCL16 and MMP9 expression.
Variants in TRIM44 Cause Aniridia by Impairing PAX6 Expression
Data show that the TRIM44-mTOR axis increases metastasis and proliferation.
High expression of TRIM44 is associated with enhanced cell proliferation, migration, invasion, and resistance to doxorubicin in hepatocellular carcinoma.

results suggest that high expression of TRIM44 is associated with poor prognosis and that TRIM44 plays significant role in cell proliferation, migration, and anti-apoptosis in testicular germ cell tumor

Mechanistic studies showed that knockdown of TRIM44 significantly reduced the levels of phosphorylated PI3K and Akt in PC-3 cells. Study provided evidence that knockdown of TRIM44 inhibited proliferation and invasion in prostate cancer cells, at least in part, through the inactivation of the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.

These results suggest that tripartite motif-containing protein 44 protein could play a crucial role in tumor invasion through its overexpression and highlight its usefulness as a predictor and potential therapeutic target in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
the TRIM44 status was an independent prognostic factor for distant disease-free survival (p = 0.005) and overall survival (p = 0.002) of patients.
Silencing of TRIM44 inhibits the proliferation, migration and invasion of papillary thyroid cancer cells.
Results suggest elevated TRIM44 promotes ICC development by inducing cell EMT and apoptosis resistance.
that TRIM44 predicts the risk of development and prognosis of endometrial cancer, highlighting its potential application as a therapeutic target for this malignancy
High TRIM44 expression is associated with multiple myeloma.
Elevated TRIM44 expression promotes human esophageal cancer development by epithelial mesenchymal transition via the AKT/mTOR pathway.
The levels of TRIM44 protein and TRIM44 mRNA in squamous cell carcinoma are both lowly expressed which is strongly associated with tumor staging, metastasis, and poor survival.

Findings suggested miR-101-3p regulated proliferation and migration of glioblastoma cells through attenuating TRIM44 induced Epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition via direct targeting 3'UTR of TRIM44, which provided preliminary study of potential therapeutic target in future glioblastoma treatment.

Studies indicate that tripartite motif containing 44 (TRIM44)expression contributes to the progression of cervical cancer, and could be used as a marker of clinical diagnosis and prognosis of patients with cervical cancer.

Study demonstrates that TRIM44 is significantly amplified in melanoma tissues, and overexpression of TRIM44 is associated with a malignant phenotype of melanoma. TRIM44 is the target of miR-26b-5p, which is significantly downregulated in melanoma tissues and may be responsible for the overexpression of TRIM44.

TRIM44 is indispensable for glioma cell proliferation and cell cycle progression through AKT/p21/p27 signaling pathway. TRIM44 was associated with oncogenic potential of glioma. Targeting TRIM44 might be beneficial for glioma therapy.
miR-192-5p suppresses the progression of lung cancer bone metastasis by targeting TRIM44.
TRIM44 promotes cell proliferation by regulating FRK.
ELFN1-AS1 accelerates the proliferation and migration of colorectal cancer via regulation of miR-4644/TRIM44 axis.
Knockdown of HIF1A-AS2 suppresses TRIM44 to protect cardiomyocytes against hypoxia-induced injury.
Down-regulation of long non-coding RNA DUXAP8 suppresses proliferation, metastasis and EMT by modulating miR-498 through TRIM44-mediated AKT/mTOR pathway in non-small-cell lung cancer.
Expression of tripartite motif-containing 44 and its prognostic and clinicopathological value in human malignancies:a meta-analysis.
The Novel Target of Colorectal Carcinoma: TRIM44 Regulates Cell Migration and Invasion via Activation of CXCR4/NF-kappaB Signaling.
MiR-34a-5p directly targeting TRIM44 affects the biological behavior of ovarian cancer cells.
Knockdown of circRAD23B Exerts Antitumor Response in Colorectal Cancer via the Regulation of miR-1205/TRIM44 axis.
TRIM44 facilitates ovarian cancer proliferation, migration, and invasion by inhibiting FRK.
TRIM44 mediated p62 deubiquitination enhances DNA damage repair by increasing nuclear FLNA and 53BP1 expression.
Long noncoding RNA LINC00858 promotes the progression of ovarian cancer via regulating the miR-134-5p/TRIM44 axis.
YTHDF1 promotes the proliferation, migration, and invasion of prostate cancer cells by regulating TRIM44.
CircFBXW8 Acts an Oncogenic Role in the Malignant Progression of Non-small Cell Lung Carcinoma by miR-370-3p-Dependent Regulation of TRIM44.
TRIM44 promotes BRCA1 functions in HR repair to induce Cisplatin Chemoresistance in Lung Adenocarcinoma by Deubiquitinating FLNA.
Clinical Significance of TRIM44 Expression in Patients with Gastric Cancer.
TRIM44 regulates tumor immunity in gastric cancer through LOXL2-dependent extracellular matrix remodeling.
Silencing LINC00491 inhibits prostate cancer development through the miR-384/TRIM44 axis.
Overexpression of TRIM44 mediates the NF-kappaB pathway to promote the progression of ovarian cancer.

BP.term: positive regulation of cytokine-mediated signaling pathway
positive regulation of defense response to virus by host
negative regulation of protein K48-linked ubiquitination
positive regulation of non-canonical NF-kappaB signal transduction

name: tripartite motif containing 44
summary: This gene encodes a member of the tripartite motif (TRIM) family. The TRIM motif includes three zinc-binding domains, namely a RING, a B-box type 1 and a B-box type 2, and a coiled-coil region. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
